text: all right well thank you everyone for
coming to this talk I think I wanted to
talk a little bit about pricing and
packaging um I'm the CEO and co-founder
of metronome for those of you who don't
know metronome is a usage billing
platform and we work with we're lucky
enough to work with any scale and number
of other companies in this room and so I
want to talk a little bit about the
lessons we've learned over the past I'd
say four years around how to price and
package and particularly how to think
about pricing and package packaging for
AI so I think the first thing that
everyone should understand or think
about is the default pricing for
software in Silicon Valley is really the
seat model the subscription model if you
sell software you probably price this
way now there's an exception like
infrastructure companies are very
clearly on usage based but traditional
SAS is really really focused on a seat
subscription model gives customers a ton
of control a ton of visibility into
their spend um and so it's like a really
ideal model for a lot of business is the
challenge is that AI doesn't really
behave like a traditional SAS product
and so seat-based pricing subscription
pricing doesn't really work very well so
why why what are the reasons for that so
the first is I'm sure all of you are
aware the underlying cost to serve a AI
model is quite high in a lot of cases
and having your pricing be kind of in a
seat model independent of costs is
really setting yourself up for failure
in a lot of ways so you know you could
launch a new product and it's it's uh
it's like a uses the hottest new open AI
libraries and if no one uses it sure
your flat fee is going to be fine but if
customers really use your product
suddenly you know choosing to charge $20
a month could easily put you into a cost
negative Place have C your most
successful customers are actually
costing you the most money that's a
really terrible place to be from a value
exchange
perspective the second reason is that if
you price in a seat-based model you're
kind of saying to the user the value you
get from this product is access to the
underlying platform which can make sense
but in a lot of cases with infra and
with AI the value is actually a lot more
granular than that it's also a lot less
like okay Bob signs into his account and
that's the value that I get in AI
especially as you start to think about
agents that like entire like the nouns
in that sentence don't even make sense
does a user actually sign into the
product is an agent a human does that
person need to be charged in a seat it
like really adds a lot of confusion to
the customer value
equation and then I think the other
thing that's really true about AI as you
can I'm sure you all know better than I
is that model capabilities for AI are
changing constantly and so as models get
better your value to the customer is
changing so you know if you're doing
your job the model is getting more
powerful it's getting IQ points or
however you reason about it the model is
getting more valuable if you are
charging a flat fee for that value then
where is your economic incentive to make
your model smarter it actually doesn't
exist and so having a flat fee as like
or a seat model as your pricing model
kind of really doesn't fit with the kind
of core conceit of AI models that are
continuously improving and getting
better over
time I think the other thing that I
would just say that kind of makes seats
not an ideal model is that pricing and
packaging the way I like to think about
it is it's it's like convergent
evolution in darwinian terms what that
means is like a population is kind of
constantly exploring for new mutations
new ways of thinking about exchanging
value with their customers and as they
Define as they like so they will like do
an experiment maybe I will charge this
one customer on a usage basis and then
if that starts to take off what it can
do is it can shift the entire market so
if you guys you know work in AI you
probably know the token model you pay
for every token that you use you might
ask yourself is tokens the really the
best way for me to exchange value with
my customers and the answer is in a lot
of cases no but the reason why you
charge in tokens is because the llm
providers charge in tokens and they took
off like wildfire and kind of set the
entire industry on their path so that
kind of darwinian kind of evolutionary
game where pricing and packaging is used
to kind of try to you know optimize for
exactly the right way to sell your
software is happening continuously and
so what that means is that you need to
listen to where the other competitors
are going and you need to either go
after and kind of charge in exactly the
same way or you know strike out on your
own and try some new brand new
evolutionary path but risk the fact that
you might that path might be a bad
branch and you have to come back to the
regress to the mean and so I think it's
really important that you kind of
understand that like pricing doesn't
exist in a vacuum pricing is in relation
to your competitors and what they
charge okay so you know I talked a lot
about why seats don't make sense what
does make sense and as a usage billing
vendor I'm going to say usage but I'll
explain why so the basic idea is like
what matters for Ai and pricing the
first thing is again kind of going back
to the fact that models are changing all
the time capabilities are changing all
the time the number one thing I advise
people to do when they're thinking about
pricing for a fast-moving emergent
Market is be flexible be iterative I
worked at Dropbox for many many years I
ran pricing and packaging for them we
were changing prices all the time you
may think that we had three prices good
better best in reality we had 3,000
prices Live at any given time in the
world
and that kind of iteration was what was
required in order for us to keep you
know kind of constantly improving the
business and I would say AI is like that
but on steroids some of our customers
you know have hundreds of thousands of
prices in the wild they are constantly
looking for what's exactly the right way
to price and then at the same time their
underlying capabilities are changing all
the time they're adding in new models
new capabilities they're constantly
changing and I would say like the main
thing that I advise almost everyone
who's thinking about pricing is hold it
Loosely do an experiment figure out the
right thing but iterate and plan to
iterate in the future now and in the
future kind of building on that last
point I think the most important thing
that you need to think about when you're
doing pricing is how can your whole job
as especially as a startup is to launch
quickly your pricing needs to match you
need to be like optimizing for what gets
you into the market as fast as you
possibly can and then you need to
iterate once you're in Market I think
like it's really important as you're
thinking about like launching a new
pricing and packaging that and iteration
Cycles is the right thing it's really
tempting to think of pricing as some
kind of precious thing that you set once
and you like you get one shot and in
reality almost every large company is
doing pricing experiments at all times
and you don't get one shot if you screw
up that's okay as long as you're open
and transparent to your customers you
can iterate and move forward and so I
would not bias toward trying to
overanalyze a lot of this stuff in fact
most of the time when we're doing
pricing internally we're trying to learn
from our customers in real time and
we're talking to customers and
constantly trying to refine exactly how
we think about
pricing I think another thing that lots
of people Miss on um specifically
consumption based pricing is that as a
consumer I kind of fundamentally hate
usage based pricing I hate not knowing
how much money I'm going to spend this
month versus next month versus the month
after that and so you as a vendor who
has to sell or wants to sell any usage
based way you have to go the extra mile
to make your product more accessible to
your end customer so so if you're a
customer of for instance data bricks or
AWS etc etc you've probably noticed they
have cost controls and cost explorers
and lots of investment into like the
internal billing dashboards that's
required because customers especially as
they scale need a lot more data and
information to build up trust that the
price that you're charging them is
mapped to the value that they're getting
and so this visibility into spend is
really really critical and really really
important for your
customers another thing that I think is
really important to consider espe as
you're engaging in this is
that a lot of businesses these days
start out in this like product Le mode
you don't have any salese people sign up
on the website maybe they don't pay you
anything and then at certain point they
graduate they grow up and then they talk
to a salesperson and get upsold etc etc
etc I think it's really important as
you're designing your usage based
business model that you plan for that
kind of handoff between a like a a
customer who's no touch and a customer
who needs a lot of handholding
what I would say is just kind of
anecdotally based on my experience in
this and the experience of my C of our
customers is that what ends up happening
is your fastest growing customers grow
at a rate that is like a power law
distribution and you really need to make
sure that those fastest growing
customers have a clean like they're
going to say I never want to talk to a
salesperson in my life and then a year
later they're going to be 10 times as
size and they're going to demand to talk
to your sales team I think what that
really means is on a usage-based Model
because the unit of value is so
continuous and unbounded in the top side
you really need to prepare a little bit
earlier than a traditional subscription
based business model for unifying
essentially the product Le motion and
the sales Le
motion I think the last thing and this
is my last slide I know we're at happy
hour I don't want to hold you back from
alcohol but there's two things that I'm
really thinking a lot about in Ai and
pricing today so the first is this
concept of outcome based pricing if
you're paying attention to like zenes
for instance they just announced this
major launch where they're basically
saying seat model is dead we're going
into an agent-based World agents their
core value in SS case is deflecting
tickets from your team so we're going to
charge you for every ticket we
successfully deflect and prevent from
Landing in your ticket queue that's
pretty extreme they're going from a
seat-based world into a pure outcome
based world I think it's like you know
to the darwinian point earlier I think
it's kind of risky for them but I also
think it's kind of smart and I'm like
watching that with a lot of like baited
breath because I do think this like
outcome based concept really does map
price to Value if you're if if if you're
building AI you're creating intelligence
how do you actually measure and quantify
the value of intelligence it's really
about the work that they're doing on
your behalf and outcomes is a pretty
good way of measuring the value of that
work I think the other thing that's
really really important kind of
dovetailing on this point is this
concept of Agents I think agents and
seats are like completely at odds with
each other like think Salesforce they
charge you for every user that has
access to the deployment um in a world
where you have 10,000 agents are you
really paying for 10,000 additional
seats in some sense creating new agents
delete seats from your account you need
zero seats and so like I do think that
this like to the extent that these
agentic workflows are starting to take
off and starting to have traction I do
think it puts an even greater level of
pressure because the idea of Agents is
that one human can now be like
superpower multiplied and um and so you
need to have a value equation where like
the basically the superpower the
multiplication The Leverage factor of
that user is Amplified and I think a
static seat model is like extremely
basic way of thinking about that problem
and is very very unlikely to actually
work so those are some things I've been
